summary: Project: HeartSense AI — a web page/web app to present and apply a Smart CVD (cardiovascular disease) risk prediction project.
architectural_notes: Deployment target requested: Internet Computer canister; provide public hosted link after deployment.
known_issues: Deployed UI includes an unwanted descriptor/banner and watermark that should be removed.
Footer currently shows an incorrect LinkedIn account link for the project owner; must be removed and replaced with the correct LinkedIn URL.

existing_features.title: Create a public-facing landing page for “HeartSense AI: Smart CVD Risk Prediction” that explains the project (what it does, who it’s for, and how to use it) and includes a clear call-to-action to start a risk assessment.

Implement a CVD risk assessment form page where a user can enter typical risk-factor inputs (at minimum: age, sex, systolic blood pressure, total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, smoking status, diabetes status) and submit to get a prediction result.

Connect the assessment form submission to the backend prediction API using the project’s standard frontend data-fetching pattern (React Query) and render a results page/section showing riskScore, riskLevel, and the explanation list, plus a “Start Over” option.

Add a medical/educational disclaimer component shown on both the landing page and the results view stating the output is for informational/educational purposes and not medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.

Apply a coherent visual theme for HeartSense AI across the app (colors, typography, spacing, components) with an accessible, health-oriented style (avoid blue/purple as primary colors) and consistent layout for navigation, content sections, and the form/results.
Add basic site navigation (header with app name and links to Home and Assessment) and a footer with project info (e.g., “HeartSense AI”) and the disclaimer link/summary.

Add generated static image assets for HeartSense AI (logo and simple health-themed hero illustration) and render them in the UI from frontend/public/assets/generated (do not serve images from the backend).
Remove the on-page descriptor/banner text from the HeartSense AI UI (the descriptor currently shown as "Smart Health Risk Prediction" in the header and landing hero).
Remove any watermark/attribution from the deployed HeartSense AI UI (including the "Built with ... caffeine.ai" line/link in the footer).

Update the risk assessment form to include a single Blood Pressure input that lets the user choose what BP value/type they are entering (e.g., systolic vs diastolic) and submit that BP selection + value as part of the assessment.

After showing the prediction result (risk score/level and contributing factors), display a “Quick tips” / “Advice” section with short, educational guidance tailored to the returned risk level (Low/Moderate/High) and include clear wording that it is not medical advice.
Make the HeartSense AI landing/home page more colorful and vibrant while keeping an accessible, health-oriented design (do not use blue/purple as the primary brand colors).
Add project owner attribution and contact details to the footer: name “Sunil Biradar”, email “sunilbiradar0066@gmail.com”, and LinkedIn “https://www.linkedin.com/in/sunil-biradar”.

Remove any watermark/attribution from the HeartSense AI UI by deleting the "Built with ❤️ using caffeine.ai" line/link from the footer so the deployed app contains no Caffeine/caffeine.ai branding or links.

Add subtle, accessible UI animations/transitions where appropriate across the app (e.g., hover/focus feedback, gentle section/card reveal on the Landing page, and smooth form-to-results transition on the Assessment page) without harming performance and with respect for reduced-motion user preferences.
Verify and enforce that the deployed UI contains no watermark/attribution text or links (including any Caffeine/caffeine.ai branding) across the landing page, assessment page, header, and footer.

Update the Project Owner LinkedIn link in the footer to remove the incorrect LinkedIn URL currently pointing to "https://www.linkedin.com/in/sunil-biradar" and replace it with the user’s correct LinkedIn profile URL. If the correct URL is not yet provided at build time, hide the LinkedIn link entirely (do not render a broken/incorrect link) until a valid URL is configured.

new_feature_requests.summary: Create a related web page/web app for the HeartSense AI Smart CVD Risk Prediction project (to present/apply the project).

Add a backend prediction API in the single Motoko actor that accepts the assessment inputs and returns a deterministic risk result containing: numeric riskScore (0–100), riskLevel (Low/Moderate/High), and an explanation array describing the main contributing factors based on the submitted inputs.
Remove the on-page descriptor/banner ("descber") and any watermark from the deployed HeartSense AI web app UI.
Update the risk assessment to include a single Blood Pressure input with selectable option (e.g., allow user to choose what BP type/value they are entering) and use it in prediction.
Make the HeartSense AI home/landing page more colorful (more vibrant visual styling).
Add project owner attribution/contact in the footer: name (Sunil Biradar), email (sunilbiradar0066@gmail.com), and LinkedIn (https://www.linkedin.com/in/sunil-biradar).
After showing the prediction result, display quick solutions/tips/advice based on the predicted risk level (educational guidance).
Add subtle UI animations/transitions where appropriate across the HeartSense AI app (e.g., hover/focus states, section reveal, form/result transitions) without harming accessibility/performance.
Deploy HeartSense AI to an Internet Computer canister and provide the public hosted link (ensure deployed UI has no watermark/attribution).

Add a deployment guide that explains how to deploy the HeartSense AI frontend and backend to the Internet Computer using dfx and how to obtain the final public URL(s) for sharing, ensuring all user-facing text is in English.
Update the footer project owner LinkedIn link: remove the incorrect LinkedIn account currently shown and replace it with the user's correct LinkedIn account URL.
